# Idea and Concept

When I first got back into making games after a longer break, I wanted to make a 2D Platformer set in an alternate version of feudal Japan.

As an initial test, I wanted to create an animated mockup of a boss fight in this game, and as one of the first pieces for that mockup, I created this character.

# Implementation

At the time of making this character, I started to use Krita for my digital art projects. This was my first pixel art creation in Krita, and my first animation, which means that I learned a lot of new skills during the creation process of this work.

For the design and animation, I used a lot of references from the game "River City Girls", as I really liked how they made their characters and thought that similar character designs would fit well for the kind of project that I wanted to make.  
The design itself is based on the traditional outfits of the Japanese shrine maidens. The red and white combination makes the character stand out from most backgrounds and makes it easy to discern between upper body and lower body, which can be very useful for some animations. But as the outfit is the same color for the arms and torso, it can be difficult sometimes to show movement between those two body partitions, as was the case for my animation, where her left arm is going across her torso.

Alternative designs:

![](data:image/png;base64,)![](data:image/png;base64,)

The skirt was the most difficult element for me to animate, as it had to move fluently with the characters' body movement, but also always needed to lag behind a bit due to its drag.  
Most of my time during animation was used for this element.

# Conclusion

I'm very happy with how the character design and animation came out. I might have relied a bit too much on the used reference materials, but it was a great experience to somewhat "reverse engineer" how professionals made their characters, and apply the knowledge gained to my own character.

Unfortunately, I never got to finish the mockup or the game, as other projects came that required my full attention. But I'm still happy with the results and experiences that I got through this little project.
